Title.evidence: Electrocoagulation vs. Radiofrequency Ablation for Great Saphenous Vein: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to EA or RFA groups using sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: 57 adults with primary chronic venous insufficiency were recruited from the Dante Pazzanese Institute of Cardiology and the Adventist Hospital of São Paulo.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to EA or RFA groups.

Objective.evidence: This study compares the long-term outcomes of electrocoagulation ablation (EA) and radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of the great saphenous vein (GSV).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was GSV occlusion, assessed via duplex ultrasound at 1 week, 3 months, 6 months, and annually.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to EA or RFA groups using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between November 2014 and May 2016, 57 patients were randomised: 28 to EA and 29 to RFA.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 57 patients were randomised: 28 to EA and 29 to RFA.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 4.8 years, occlusion rates were 89.7% for EA and 66.7% for RFA (P = .001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups.
